title: RL32930
content: The NLRA, as amended, governs labor-management relations in the private sector by improving workers' bargaining power. It allows workers to join or form a union, bargain collectively, and protects their right not to join. Employers must negotiate in good faith with a union chosen by the majority of employees. The NLRA allows workers to join or form a union, bargain collectively over wages and conditions of employment, and protects their right not to join. The act requires employers to negotiate in good faith with a union chosen by the majority of employees. The NLRB administers and enforces the NLRA, resolving objections to elections, deciding on bargaining unit composition, and hearing appeals of unfair labor practices. The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) consists of a five-member board and a General Counsel. The board resolves objections and challenges to secret ballot elections, decides on bargaining unit composition, and hears appeals of unfair labor practices. The General Counsel's office conducts secret ballot elections, investigates complaints of unfair labor practices, and supervises regional and field offices. Bargaining units are groups of employees represented by a union, determined based on a "community of interest." In a specific case, certified nursing assistants (CNAs) at a healthcare center petitioned to be represented by a union, and the NLRB found their unit to be appropriate despite the employer's request to include other nonprofessional service and maintenance employees. The CNAs at the healthcare center requested a review of the decision regarding their bargaining unit, arguing that it should only include nonprofessional service and maintenance employees. They assist residents with daily functions, wear nursing uniforms, and are supervised by licensed practical nurses. The employer argued that other employees like resident activity assistants, a staffing coordinator, a maintenance assistant, a medical records clerk, and cooks should be included in the bargaining unit. These employees have similar educational requirements as the CNAs. The CNAs at the healthcare center, along with other employees, were part of a dispute over their bargaining unit. The board ultimately sided with the CNAs, determining that they shared a community of interest due to their distinct training, certification, supervision, uniforms, pay rates, work assignments, shifts, and work areas. The other employees, such as resident activity assistants and maintenance assistants, have similar educational requirements but are not required to work specific shifts like the CNAs. The board agreed that the CNAs shared a community of interest due to their distinct training, certification, supervision, uniforms, pay rates, work assignments, shifts, and work areas.
